title: Batch processing / queue support
description:
Problem
- No native batch processing; users must script around CLI.

Goal
- Add batch input and output for multiple items.

Scope
- New `iwantit run --batch <file>` or similar.
- Per-item result records + summary.
- Failures isolated to item level.

Non-goals
- Distributed queueing.

Acceptance criteria
- Batch mode processes N inputs and returns N results.
- Per-item errors do not stop the batch.
- Summary includes counts for success/needs_choice/error.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- Batch mode processes N inputs and returns N results.
- Per-item errors do not stop the batch.
- Summary includes counts for success/needs_choice/error.

title: Interactive chooser enhancements (preview/explain)
description:
Problem
- `iwantit choose` is minimal and hard to use with large candidate sets.

Goal
- Improve chooser UX with preview and explain modes.

Scope
- Add `--preview` to show selected candidate details.
- Add `--explain` to show ranking reasons.
- Add filtering flags (min score, year, format).

Non-goals
- Full TUI.

Acceptance criteria
- `iwantit choose --preview` shows candidate details.
- `iwantit choose --explain` shows ranking reasons.
- Filters reduce displayed options correctly.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- `iwantit choose --preview` shows candidate details.
- `iwantit choose --explain` shows ranking reasons.
- Filters reduce displayed options correctly.

title: Provider test harness and fixtures
description:
Problem
- Provider parsers are brittle without fixtures.

Goal
- Add fixtures and a harness for provider parsing tests.

Scope
- Fixture files for at least 2 providers.
- Test harness reads fixture and validates mapping.

Non-goals
- Full integration tests with live providers.

Acceptance criteria
- Fixture-based tests run in CI.
- At least 2 providers have fixtures.
- Parsing regressions fail tests.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- Fixture-based tests run in CI.
- At least 2 providers have fixtures.
- Parsing regressions fail tests.

title: Canonical metadata model + provenance tracking
description:
Problem
- Field names are ad-hoc and provenance is not tracked, leading to conflicts and opaque overrides.

Goal
- Define a canonical metadata model and track provenance for each field.

Scope
- Define schema per media type (music/movie/tv/book) with canonical fields.
- Track provenance for each field: source (url/search/provider), timestamp, confidence.
- Deterministic conflict resolution rules.

Non-goals
- Full metadata normalization for all providers.

Acceptance criteria
- Canonical schema exists and is documented.
- Output JSON includes provenance for canonical fields.
- Conflict resolution is deterministic and tested.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- Canonical schema exists and is documented.
- Output JSON includes provenance for canonical fields.
- Conflict resolution is deterministic and tested.

title: Provider rate limiting and quota enforcement
description:
Problem
- Providers can rate-limit; current retry logic is generic and can cause bans.

Goal
- Enforce per-provider rate limits and quotas.

Scope
- Track per-provider requests/time window.
- Backoff/pacing configurable per provider.
- Integrate with retry logic.

Non-goals
- Distributed rate limiting.

Acceptance criteria
- Rate limits enforced per provider.
- Backoff policy configurable in config.
- Unit tests cover rate limiting.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- Rate limits enforced per provider.
- Backoff policy configurable in config.
- Unit tests cover rate limiting.

title: Step metadata contract (side effects, inputs, outputs)
description:
Problem
- Steps do not describe their inputs/outputs or whether they are side-effecting, forcing hardcoded safety logic.

Goal
- Add step metadata that is machine-readable and drives safety gating, validation, and docs.

Scope
- Define a metadata structure for each builtin step: side_effect (bool), requires (fields), emits (fields), optional (fields), description.
- Expose metadata in CLI help and validate.
- Ensure side-effect steps are discovered via metadata (not hardcoded).

Non-goals
- Changing step behavior beyond metadata usage.

Implementation notes
- Metadata can live next to BUILTINS or in a registry (e.g., steps/metadata.py).
- External steps may optionally declare metadata in config.

Acceptance criteria
- Each builtin step has metadata with side_effect, requires, emits.
- CLI help/doctor can list side-effect steps dynamically.
- Safety gating uses metadata instead of a hardcoded list.
- Validation can check that required inputs exist before running a step (at least in dry validation).
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- Each builtin step has metadata with side_effect, requires, emits.
- CLI help/doctor can list side-effect steps dynamically.
- Safety gating uses metadata instead of a hardcoded list.
- Validation can check that required inputs exist before running a step (at least in dry validation).

title: Centralized redaction policy for logs/artifacts
description:
Problem
- Redaction is scattered; secrets can leak into logs or stored artifacts.

Goal
- Centralize redaction to ensure consistent sanitization.

Scope
- One redaction utility applies to all logs/artifacts/output.
- Tests for redacting API keys, tokens, auth headers, and URLs with secrets.

Non-goals
- Encrypting all logs.

Acceptance criteria
- All logs/artifacts pass through redaction utility.
- Tests cover at least 5 secret patterns.
- No secrets appear in example output.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- All logs/artifacts pass through redaction utility.
- Tests cover at least 5 secret patterns.
- No secrets appear in example output.

title: Concurrency controls and parallelism
description:
Problem
- Future provider expansion will demand concurrency without exceeding limits.

Goal
- Add configurable parallelism with safe defaults.

Scope
- Configurable concurrency per step/provider.
- Respect rate limits and backoff.

Non-goals
- Distributed job scheduling.

Acceptance criteria
- Concurrency can be set per provider/step.
- Parallel execution does not exceed rate limits.
- Defaults preserve existing single-thread behavior.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- Concurrency can be set per provider/step.
- Parallel execution does not exceed rate limits.
- Defaults preserve existing single-thread behavior.

title: Deduplication and candidate merge strategy
description:
Problem
- Multiple providers return duplicates, causing noisy candidate lists and inconsistent ranking.

Goal
- Deduplicate candidates and merge data safely with provenance.

Scope
- Dedup by canonical keys (artist/title/year/ids) with fuzzy fallback.
- Merge fields with provenance; preserve source list.
- Should not drop unique fields.

Non-goals
- Perfect fuzzy matching.

Acceptance criteria
- Duplicate candidates are merged with provenance preserved.
- Candidate count decreases without losing unique fields.
- Dedupe behavior is configurable.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- Duplicate candidates are merged with provenance preserved.
- Candidate count decreases without losing unique fields.
- Dedupe behavior is configurable.

title: Run IDs and structured step logs
description:
Problem
- Debugging across runs is difficult without a stable run ID and structured logs.

Goal
- Introduce run IDs and structured step logs for start/end/duration/error.

Scope
- Generate a run_id per invocation and include in output JSON.
- Log per-step events with timestamp, duration, status, and message.
- Allow optional log file location via config/flag.

Non-goals
- Full tracing infrastructure.

Acceptance criteria
- Each run has a run_id in output JSON.
- A step log is produced with start/end + duration for each step.
- Log file output works when configured.
- Logs are redacted for secrets.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- Each run has a run_id in output JSON.
- A step log is produced with start/end + duration for each step.
- Log file output works when configured.
- Logs are redacted for secrets.

title: Provider registry with capabilities and validation
description:
Problem
- Providers are config-only and lack a formal contract, so validation and help cannot reliably derive required keys or capabilities.

Goal
- Introduce a provider registry that formally describes provider capabilities, required config keys, auth scheme, rate limits, and response mapping hints, and use it everywhere validation/help needs provider knowledge.

Scope
- A central registry module (e.g., registry/providers.py) with built-in provider definitions.
- Registry entries support: name, media_types, auth scheme, required_keys, optional_keys, rate_limit (requests/min), response_map hints, supports_url_inputs (bool), supports_web_search (bool), supports_metadata (bool).
- Validation uses registry to emit missing/invalid configuration warnings/errors.
- Help/doctor surfaces required keys per provider based on registry.
- Custom providers can be registered via config without modifying code (e.g., provider registry accepts unknown provider with minimal schema).

Non-goals
- Implementing new providers or changing provider APIs.

Implementation notes
- Keep default config backward compatible.
- Registry should tolerate provider entries missing optional fields.

Acceptance criteria
- A provider registry exists in code and is used by validation/help.
- Each built-in provider definition includes auth scheme and required keys.
- `iwantit validate` reports missing provider keys with provider-specific messages.
- `iwantit help config` (or doctor) lists required keys based on registry.
- Existing config files continue to work without modification.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- A provider registry exists in code and is used by validation/help.
- Each built-in provider definition includes auth scheme and required keys.
- `iwantit validate` reports missing provider keys with provider-specific messages.
- `iwantit help config` (or doctor) lists required keys based on registry.
- Existing config files continue to work without modification.

title: Config schema validation (JSON schema or pydantic)
description:
Problem
- Config validation is ad-hoc and misses structural errors; errors are not actionable enough for automation.

Goal
- Introduce a formal schema for config to provide clear, actionable validation.

Scope
- Define schema for top-level config, providers, steps, and workflows.
- `iwantit validate` uses the schema and returns structured error messages.
- Schema should allow extensions for custom providers/steps.

Non-goals
- Enforcing provider-specific runtime connectivity.

Implementation notes
- Use JSON Schema or Pydantic; must be versioned and backward compatible.

Acceptance criteria
- A schema exists and is used by `iwantit validate`.
- Validation errors include path + message (e.g., `prowlarr.api_key: missing`).
- Custom providers/steps are accepted via extension points in the schema.
- Existing config passes validation with no changes.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- A schema exists and is used by `iwantit validate`.
- Validation errors include path + message (e.g., `prowlarr.api_key: missing`).
- Custom providers/steps are accepted via extension points in the schema.
- Existing config passes validation with no changes.

title: Plugin discovery and packaging for external steps
description:
Problem
- External commands are supported but not discoverable or versioned.

Goal
- Add plugin discovery and versioned metadata for external steps.

Scope
- Discover plugins from a directory or entry points.
- Plugins declare name, version, steps provided.
- Document plugin format.

Non-goals
- Remote plugin installation.

Acceptance criteria
- Plugins discovered automatically and listed in `iwantit list`.
- Plugin metadata includes version and step names.
- Docs describe how to build a plugin.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- Plugins discovered automatically and listed in `iwantit list`.
- Plugin metadata includes version and step names.
- Docs describe how to build a plugin.

title: Guided setup / doctor for integrations
description:
Problem
- New users must hand-edit config and guess missing requirements.

Goal
- Provide guided setup or doctor that validates configuration and connectivity.

Scope
- New `iwantit doctor` or `iwantit setup` command.
- Checks: config exists, required provider keys, connectivity to prowlarr/radarr/sonarr, and web search keys.
- Emits actionable fixes.

Non-goals
- Auto-writing secrets.

Acceptance criteria
- `iwantit doctor` reports missing keys with specific fixes.
- Connectivity checks produce clear pass/fail results.
- Command exits non-zero if required checks fail.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- `iwantit doctor` reports missing keys with specific fixes.
- Connectivity checks produce clear pass/fail results.
- Command exits non-zero if required checks fail.

title: Structured error taxonomy with remediation hints
description:
Problem
- Errors are stringly typed; automation cannot reliably distinguish auth errors, rate limits, or parse errors.

Goal
- Standardize error codes and include remediation hints in results.

Scope
- Define error codes (AUTH_MISSING, AUTH_FAILED, RATE_LIMITED, NETWORK_ERROR, PARSE_ERROR, CONFIG_ERROR, TIMEOUT, NOT_FOUND).
- Ensure all steps emit errors in a consistent shape: {code, message, step, hint}.
- Docs list common codes and suggested fixes.

Non-goals
- Changing third-party error messages beyond wrapping them.

Acceptance criteria
- All error results include a code and hint.
- `iwantit run` surfaces standardized error codes in JSON output.
- Docs list the codes with suggested remediation.
- At least 3 different error sources are mapped (network, auth, parse).
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- All error results include a code and hint.
- `iwantit run` surfaces standardized error codes in JSON output.
- Docs list the codes with suggested remediation.
- At least 3 different error sources are mapped (network, auth, parse).

title: Confidence scoring v2 (multi-signal)
description:
Problem
- Confidence is a single rank delta and ignores metadata completeness or provider signals.

Goal
- Implement a multi-signal confidence model.

Scope
- Signals include: match ratio, metadata completeness, provider confidence, consistency across sources, rank delta.
- Expose score breakdown in output.
- Threshold configurable per media type.

Non-goals
- ML model.

Acceptance criteria
- Confidence score combines at least 4 signals.
- Output includes score breakdown.
- Thresholds configurable per media type.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- Confidence score combines at least 4 signals.
- Output includes score breakdown.
- Thresholds configurable per media type.

title: Human-readable run report artifact
description:
Problem
- JSON output is hard for humans; no summary artifact exists.

Goal
- Provide an optional run report for humans.

Scope
- Create a markdown/text report summarizing query, parsed fields, candidates, decision, and warnings.
- Link report to run_id and save under state directory.

Non-goals
- Rich UI.

Acceptance criteria
- When enabled, a report file is written under state dir.
- Report includes query, media type, selected candidate, confidence, and warnings.
- Report path is emitted in output JSON.
acceptance_criteria:
Acceptance criteria
- When enabled, a report file is written under state dir.
- Report includes query, media type, selected candidate, confidence, and warnings.
- Report path is emitted in output JSON.
